title: 112_s3084
content:
The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" is the short title of the Act. It deals with the administration of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The "VISN Reorganization Act of 2012" amends Subchapter I of chapter 73 of title 38, United States Code, by adding a new section on Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The Secretary is required to organize the Veterans Health Administration into 12 geographically defined Networks aligned with the Department's mission and specific healthcare requirements of each veteran population. The Secretary ensures alignment of staff, services, and programs in 12 Veterans Integrated Service Networks with the Department's mission and specific healthcare needs of veterans. Each network implements national goals and operates as an integrated health care system. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network implements national goals and maintains an integrated healthcare system by forming alliances with other healthcare organizations. The Secretary ensures that each Veterans Integrated Service Network maintains a regional integrated healthcare system by forming alliances with other healthcare organizations and managing a regional budget aligned with Department guidelines. The Secretary oversees and manages a regional budget for the Veterans Health Administration in the Network's geographic area, ensuring alignment with Department guidelines and balancing it annually. They also use national metrics to develop systems for effective, efficient, and safe healthcare delivery rated highly satisfactory by patients and families. The Secretary ensures the regional budget for the Veterans Health Administration in the Network is balanced annually and uses national metrics to develop systems for highly satisfactory healthcare delivery. High-quality clinical programs and services are provided through medical centers, outpatient clinics, and non-Department healthcare facilities. The Secretary ensures high-quality clinical programs and services are provided through medical centers, outpatient clinics, and non-Department healthcare facilities in the Network, while reducing duplication of functions in the Veterans Health Administration. The Secretary ensures that the Veterans Integrated Service Networks reduce duplication of functions and collaborate for maximum effectiveness in patient care, safety, education, and research. The Secretary ensures collaboration and cooperation among Veteran Integrated Service Networks to maximize patient care, safety, education, and research, including assessing consolidation of functions with other entities in the geographical area. The Secretary collaborates with other Veterans Integrated Service Networks and offices/entities within the geographical area, including Veterans Benefits Administration, National Cemetery Administration, and Department of Defense offices/facilities. The Department of Defense, Coast Guard, State and local agencies, and medical schools are among the offices and facilities that collaborate with the Secretary to provide assistance to veterans. The Secretary collaborates with various entities to provide assistance to veterans, including the Armed Forces, Coast Guard, State and local agencies, medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, and community organizations. The Secretary collaborates with various entities to provide assistance to veterans, including medical schools, government offices, emergency preparedness organizations, community organizations, and other Federal Government offices as deemed appropriate. The Veterans Integrated Service Networks are tasked with developing and sharing innovations and best practices among each other. The Secretary collaborates with various entities to assist veterans, including medical schools, government offices, and emergency preparedness organizations. The Veterans Integrated Service Networks are responsible for developing and sharing innovations and best practices at local, regional, and national levels. Each network is required to have one headquarters office located at a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The Secretary ensures each Veterans Integrated Service Network has one headquarters co-located with a VA medical center, employing up to 65 employees. Annual reports are submitted to the Senate Committee on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary may employ up to 65 employees at each Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters. Annual reports on employment must be submitted to the Senate and House Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The House Committee on Veterans' Affairs requires annual reports on employment at Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters, detailing the number of employees and their positions. The House Committee on Veterans' Affairs requires annual reports on employment at Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters, including the number of employees, their positions, and budget impact assessment. The House Committee on Veterans' Affairs mandates annual reports on employment at Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters, detailing the number of employees, positions, and budget impact assessment. Additionally, a triennial review, reassessment, and report on the structure will be conducted every three years. The Secretary will conduct a triennial review and assessment of the structure and operations of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks, submitting a report to the Committees of Veterans' Affairs every three years. The Secretary will review and assess the structure and operations of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks every three years, submitting recommendations for improvement to the Committees of Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary will conduct a review and assessment of the Veterans Integrated Service Networks every three years, providing recommendations for legislative or regulatory action to enhance their operations. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks within one year of the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will consolidate the 21 Veterans Integrated Service Networks into 12 geographically defined networks as follows:
- Veterans Integrated Service Network 1, 2, and 3 will be combined into one network.
- Veterans Integrated Service Network 4 and 5 will be combined into one network. Integrated Service Network 2, 3, 4, 5, 9, 10, and 11 will be combined into fewer Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 2, 3, 4, 5, 9, 10, 11, 12, 15, and 23 will be combined into fewer networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 12, 15, 17, 18, 19, and 20 will be combined into fewer networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, and 22 will be consolidated into fewer networks. Veterans Integrated Service Networks 20, 21, and 22 will be combined into fewer networks, with one headquarters retained for each consolidated set. The consolidation of Veterans Integrated Service Networks will result in one headquarters being retained for each set, eliminating any additional headquarters to meet requirements. The Act will retain one headquarters for each set, eliminating any additional headquarters to comply with section 7309(h) of title 38, United States Code. Measures will be taken to find new positions for individuals whose employment is affected by the elimination of headquarters. The Secretary will find new positions within the Department of Veterans Affairs for individuals whose employment is affected by the elimination of headquarters. An implementation plan must be submitted to the Committee of Veterans' Affairs within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will find new positions within the Department of Veterans Affairs for affected employees. An implementation plan must be submitted to the Committee of Veterans' Affairs within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary may relocate a headquarters office of a Veterans Integrated Service Network that was not co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center upon lease expiration. The Secretary has the authority to relocate a Veterans Integrated Service Network headquarters office that is not co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center upon lease expiration. The Secretary can either relocate the headquarters office or renew the lease to keep it in the current location, with a requirement to report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs if a lease is renewed or a new lease is entered into. The Secretary can renew or engage in a new lease for the headquarters office, with a requirement to report to the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The report must include reasons for the renewal or engagement and a list of underutilized medical centers in the Veterans Integrated Service Network. Before renewing or engaging in a lease for the headquarters office, a report must be submitted with reasons for the renewal or engagement. The report should include a list of underutilized medical centers in the Veterans Integrated Service Network, along with the cost of the current lease. The report must include details on underutilized buildings in the network, the cost of current and new leases, and square footage information for each medical center. SEC. 3. REGIONAL SUPPORT CENTERS FOR VETERANS INTEGRATED SERVICE NETWORKS. The Secretary shall establish up to four regional support centers within the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Each center will report to the Under Secretary of Health and perform specified functions. The Secretary will establish four regional support centers in the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. Each center will report to the Under Secretary of Health and assess finance operations, compliance activities, and outreach efforts within the networks. The Secretary will establish regional support centers in the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of Veterans Integrated Service Networks. The centers will assess finance operations, compliance activities, outreach efforts to veterans of specific operations, and programs for women veterans. The Secretary will establish regional support centers in the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of Veterans Integrated Service Networks in serving veterans from specific operations, women veterans, addressing homelessness, and energy consumption. The Secretary will establish regional support centers in the Veterans Health Administration to evaluate the effectiveness of Veterans Integrated Service Networks in serving veterans, addressing homelessness, and energy consumption. The centers will also assess other relevant operations and activities as deemed appropriate by the Secretary. Staff may be hired to support the functions of the regional support centers. The Secretary may hire employees and contractors for the regional support centers, which will be located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center. The Secretary determines the location of regional support centers, which are co-located with Department of Veterans Affairs medical centers. However, the Secretary can choose a different location with approval from the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The Secretary can choose a location for a regional support center that is not co-located with a Department of Veterans Affairs medical center, with approval from the Committees on Veterans' Affairs. The report must list underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network of the regional support center. The report must list underutilized buildings in the Veterans Integrated Service Network of the regional support center, including the number of buildings and total underutilized square footage for each medical center in the network. If the Secretary leases a location for the regional support center, the report must include the cost of the lease. The report must include the number of buildings and total underutilized square footage for each medical center in the Veterans Integrated Service Network. It should also detail the cost of any lease for the regional support center, including annual rent, total cost over the lease's life, and cost per square foot. The report must include details on the lease for the regional support center, such as annual rent, total cost over the lease's life, and cost per square foot. Additionally, the Secretary should transfer employees from headquarters to regional support centers for initial staffing. The Secretary should transfer employees from headquarters to regional support centers for initial staffing, covering functions similar to those described in section 7309A(b) of the title. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections in chapter 73. SEC. 4. CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not require any changes in the location or type of medical care provided by Department of Veterans Affairs facilities.
